message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Proceedings of the 30th International Conference on Intelligent User Interfaces
Paper Abstract: user interfaces mediate between person and machine to increase the ease and effectiveness of user interactions. Research in intelligent user interfaces draws on areas such as artificial and human-computer interaction to study methods for supporting varied users for a wide range of tasks, task environments, platforms, and interaction paradigms. The IUI conference is the annual meeting of the intelligent interfaces community, and serves as the principal international forum for reporting outstanding research and development in intelligent user interfaces. IUI'03, the Seventh IUI, was held at The Palms South Beach hotel in Miami Beach, Florida, USA, from January 12-15, 2003. special theme of the conference was highlighting interfaces whose focus goes beyond rational intelligence to address psychological concerns such as emotion, personality, and motivationIUI'03 solicited submissions in three categories, long papers, describing mature work; short papers, describing work in progress, and brief abstracts of system demonstrations. The conference received 134 submissions, an all-time record, including 80 long papers and 49 short papers. Based on rigorous review by an international program committee, 28 papers were selected for oral presentation, with 45 additional submissions featured as posters and demonstrations. Oral presentations spanned the areas of adaptive and collaborative interfaces, affective interfaces, agent-based interfaces, knowledge acquisition and visualization, model-based interface design, multimodal input, and natural language interfacesThe conference program highlighted three invited talks: Daniel Weld presented What Users Want, Hiroshi Ishii presented Tangible Bits: Designing the Seamless Interface between People, Bits, and Atoms, and Allen Gorin presented Semantic Information Processing of Spoken Language in 'How May I Help You?'  (sm). The panel A Life without Friction: Tales from the InfoLab, chaired by Kristian Hammond and Larry Birnbaum, gave an in-depth view of IUI research at the Information Laboratory of Northwestern University, and the panel XML: The Lingua Franca of IUIs?, chaired by Angel Puerta, examined the role of standardization of interoperation and data interchange in the IUI software industry. The conference opened with two tutorials, Intelligent User Interfaces: An Introduction, by Mark Maybury, and Recommender Systems: Interfaces and Technology, by John Riedl and Joseph Konstan
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about Human-Computer Interaction:

## Definition

Human-computer interaction (HCI) is "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them," according to the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM).

## Key Concepts

The term conveys that computers have many uses which often involve an open-ended dialogue between the user and the computer, likening human-computer interaction to human-to-human interaction—an analogy crucial to theoretical considerations in the field.(no content)HCI draws from supporting knowledge on both the machine and human sides. On the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant, while on the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, and human factors are relevant.

## Interaction Modalities

The field encompasses various interaction approaches, including:
- Facial expression analysis for visually recognizing and analyzing emotions
- Gesture recognition for identifying and interpreting gestures made by users
- Gaze detection involving tracking eye movement to understand user attention and intent

## Historical Context

The first known use of the term HCI was in 1975 by Carlisle.

Human-Computer Interaction remains a vital interdisciplinary field that continues to evolve with advancing technologies.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's information about Human-Computer Interaction:

## Definition

Human-computer interaction (HCI) is "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them," according to the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM).

## Key Concepts

The term conveys that computers have many uses which often involve an open-ended dialogue between the user and the computer, likening human-computer interaction to human-to-human interaction—an analogy crucial to theoretical considerations in the field.(no content)HCI draws from supporting knowledge on both the machine and human sides. On the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant, while on the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, and human factors are relevant.

## Interaction Modalities

The field encompasses various interaction approaches, including:
- Facial expression analysis for visually recognizing and analyzing emotions
- Gesture recognition for identifying and interpreting gestures made by users
- Gaze detection involving tracking eye movement to understand user attention and intent

## Historical Context

The first known use of the term HCI was in 1975 by Carlisle.

Human-Computer Interaction remains a vital interdisciplinary field that continues to evolve with advancing technologies.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Natural Language Processing (NLP):

## Definition and Overview

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer, and it's a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

## Related Fields

NLP is related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

The search results provide comprehensive information about NLP's definition, historical evolution, and current state of the field.

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

I've successfully performed a web search for "Artificial Intelligence." Here's a summary of the findings:

## Overview

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Key Areas and Applications

The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.(no content)Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

AI has been applied across numerous industries, including architecture, contact centers, media analysis, surveillance, music composition, and more.

## Artificial General Intelligence

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

## Current Concerns

The report states that power demand for AI uses might double by 2026, with additional electric power usage equal to electricity used by the whole Japanese nation. Prodigious power consumption by AI is responsible for the growth of fossil fuel use, and might delay closings of obsolete, carbon-emitting coal energy facilities.

The search results also covered various specialized topics including AI in video games, AI art, military applications, and ethical considerations surrounding AI development and deployment.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of XML:

## What is XML?

Extensible Markup Language (XML) is a markup language and file format for storing, transmitting, and reconstructing data.(no content)It defines a set of rules for encoding documents in a format that is both human-readable and machine-readable.

## Key Characteristics

The design goals of XML emphasize simplicity, generality, and usability across the Internet.(no content)As a markup language, XML labels, categorizes, and structurally organizes information. ## Search Results: Intelligent User Interfaces

Here's what I found about Intelligent User Interfaces:

### Definition and Overview

An intelligent user interface (intelligent UI, IUI, or sometimes interface agent) is a user interface (UI) that involves some aspect of artificial intelligence (AI or computational intelligence). More specifically, intelligent user interfaces are human–machine interfaces that aim to improve the efficiency, effectiveness, and naturalness of human–machine interaction by representing, reasoning, and acting on models of the user, domain, task, discourse, and media (e.g., graphics, natural language, gesture).

### Historical Development

In the early 1980s, as expert systems took hold in the AI community, expert systems were applied to UIs (e.g., the aptly-named "WIZARD" system).(no content)In the 1990s the application of plan inference to interaction formed the basis for research in what then was named natural interfaces.(no content)Later IUIs, such as Clippy, are more statistically-based, using machine learning methods to decide how to tune the interactive experience to the individual user. In the 2000s this strand of research often is labeled personalization, most often employing various recommender system techniques to adapt the behavior of an interface or an entire interactive system to individual user preferences.

### Research Community

Research in intelligent user interfaces is published in general Human-Computer Interaction conferences and journals such as CHI or UIST as well as in some artificial intelligence research channels such as those hosted by the AAAI, but most importantly there are the dedicated conference series on Intelligent User Interfaces (since 1988) and Recommender Systems (since 2007), as well as the journal User Modeling and User-Adapted Interaction (since 1990).

I found comprehensive information about Affective Computing. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Affective computing is the study and development of systems and devices that can recognize, interpret, process, and simulate human affects.(no content)It is an interdisciplinary field spanning computer science, psychology, and cognitive science.

## Origins and Key Figures

The more modern branch of computer science originated with Rosalind Picard's 1995 paper entitled "Affective Computing" and her 1997 book of the same name published by MIT Press.(no content)One of the motivations for the research is the ability to give machines emotional intelligence, including to simulate empathy.

## Core Objectives

The machine should interpret the emotional state of humans and adapt its behavior to them, giving an appropriate response to those emotions.

## Technologies Used

This is done using machine learning techniques that process different modalities, such as speech recognition, natural language processing, or facial expression detection.

## Applications

Another area within affective computing is the design of computational devices proposed to exhibit either innate emotional capabilities or that are capable of convincingly simulating emotions. Practical applications include emotion recognition systems for various industries, from healthcare to marketing.

The field continues to evolve with advances in AI and sensor technology, enabling more sophisticated emotion recognition and human-computer interaction capabilities.

## Recommender Systems - Search Results

I've found comprehensive information about recommender systems. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Purpose

A recommender system, also called a recommendation algorithm, recommendation engine, or recommendation platform, is a type of information filtering system that suggests items most relevant to a particular user.(no content)The value of these systems becomes particularly evident in scenarios where users must select from a large number of options, such as products, media, or content.

### Main Approaches

Recommender systems use several primary techniques:

1. **Collaborative Filtering**: Collaborative filtering approaches build a model from a user's past behavior (e.g., items previously purchased or selected and/or numerical ratings given to those items) as well as similar decisions made by other users. This model is then used to predict items (or ratings for items) that the user may have an interest in.

2. **Content-Based Filtering**: Content-based filtering approaches utilize a series of discrete, pre-tagged characteristics of an item in order to recommend additional items with similar properties.

Links: [{"title":"Multimodal interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_interaction"},{"title":"Multisensory integration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multisensory_integration"},{"title":"Multimodal learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_learning"},{"title":"Multimodal search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_search"},{"title":"Trajectory inference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectory_inference"},{"title":"Prompt injection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prompt_injection"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about multimodal input:

## Overview

Multimodal systems allow users to interact through input modalities, such as speech, handwriting, hand gesture and gaze, and to receive information by the system through output modalities, such as speech synthesis, smart graphics and other modalities, opportunely combined.

## Key Characteristics

Multimodal human-computer interaction refers to the "interaction with the virtual and physical environment through natural modes of communication", enabling a more free and natural communication, interfacing users with automated systems in both input and output.(no content)A multimodal system has to recognize the inputs from the different modalities combining them according to temporal and contextual constraints in order to allow their interpretation, in a process known as multimodal fusion.

## Benefits and Applications

The advantage of multiple input modalities is increased usability: the weaknesses of one modality are offset by the strengths of another.(no content)Multimodal input user interfaces have implications for accessibility, as a well-designed multimodal application can be used by people with a wide variety of impairments.

## Machine Learning Context

Multimodal learning is a type of deep learning that integrates and processes multiple types of data, referred to as modalities, such as text, audio, images, or video, allowing for a more holistic understanding of complex data, improving model performance in tasks like visual question answering, cross-modal retrieval, text-to-image generation, aesthetic ranking, and image captioning.

Based on the search results, here's information about Collaborative Interface:

## Overview

A collaborative interface is a component of systems designed to facilitate teamwork and group cooperation. In 1991, educator C. A. Ellis defined "groupware" as "computer-based systems that support groups of people engaged in a common task (or goal) and that provide an interface to a shared environment".

## Business Interoperability Interface (BII)

One specific type is the Business Interoperability Interface (BII). A business interoperability interface (BII) is an interface that enables business interoperability between organizational systems. The interface comprises those elements of a collaborative business process, which are provided by the organization itself, as well as the elements, the organization expects from partner organizations.

## Key Functions

Collaborative interfaces serve several important purposes:

- Communication tools provide exchange of information between individuals, with email being a key example that changed workplace communication
- They provide group awareness by giving information about collaborators' status and activities, and workspace awareness through a common workspace where groups can discuss findings and create common products

## Modern Applications

Collabora Online enables real-time collaborative editing of documents, spreadsheets, presentations, and vector graphics in a web browser, representing a modern example of collaborative interface technology.

## Overview

A collaborative interface is a component of systems designed to facilitate teamwork and group cooperation. In 1991, educator C. A. Ellis defined "groupware" as "computer-based systems that support groups of people engaged in a common task (or goal) and that provide an interface to a shared environment".

## Business Interoperability Interface (BII)

One specific type is the Business Interoperability Interface (BII). A business interoperability interface (BII) is an interface that enables business interoperability between organizational systems. The interface comprises those elements of a collaborative business process, which are provided by the organization itself, as well as the elements, the organization expects from partner organizations.

## Key Functions

Collaborative interfaces serve several important purposes:

- Communication tools provide exchange of information between individuals, with email being a key example that changed workplace communication
- They provide group awareness by giving information about collaborators' status and activities, and workspace awareness through a common workspace where groups can discuss findings and create common products

## Modern Applications

Collabora Online enables real-time collaborative editing of documents, spreadsheets, presentations, and vector graphics in a web browser, representing a modern example of collaborative interface technology.

Based on the search results, here's information about Model-based Interface Design:

## Overview

Model-based user interface development environments (MB-UIDE) are systems that develop user interfaces using computational models. This approach is part of a broader field called user interface modeling, where the modeling task shows how the actual presentation of a planned system and how user interaction is supposed to happen.

## Key Models Used

Different aspects of a user interface require different model types, including: Domain model (defining the objects that a user can view and manipulate), Navigation model (defining how objects can be navigated), Task model (describing the tasks an end user performs), User model (representing different characteristics of end users), Platform model (modeling physical devices), Dialogue model (how users interact with objects and media), Presentation model (application appearance and visual elements), and Application model (commands and data the application provides).

## Related Approaches

Several architectural patterns support model-based interface design:

- Model–view–viewmodel (MVVM) is an architectural pattern that facilitates the separation of graphical user interface development from business logic development

- UsiXML (USer Interface eXtensible Markup Language) is an XML-based specification language for user interface design that supports description of UI for multiple contexts including Character User Interfaces, Graphical User Interfaces, Auditory User Interfaces, and Multimodal User Interfaces

- The Interaction Flow Modeling Language (IFML) is a standardized modeling language that includes graphic notations to create visual models of user interactions and front-end behavior in software systems

## Adaptive User Interface - Search Results

Here's what I found about Adaptive User Interfaces:

### Definition
An adaptive user interface (AUI) is a user interface which adapts, that is changes, its layout and elements to the needs of the user or context and is similarly alterable by each user.

### Key Characteristics
The interface's components have mutually reciprocal qualities of both adapting and being adaptable, and portions of the interface might adapt to and affect other portions of the interface.

### Advantages
Adaptive user interfaces have the ability to conform to users' needs by showing only relevant information based on the current user, which creates less confusion for less experienced users and provides ease of access throughout a system.

### Applications
One common implementation of an AUI is in the medical industry, where it is used to differentiate and specify which information should be shown to which type of user.

### Adaptation Methods

**Adaptive Presentation:** The goal is to display certain information based on the current user, meaning users with basic knowledge are shown minimal information, while users with advanced knowledge have access to more detailed information and capabilities.

**Adaptive Navigation:** Adaptive navigation intends to guide a user to their specific goal within the system by altering the way the system is navigated based on factors such as the user's expertise level and current goal within the system.

### Challenges
AUIs must be designed with varying levels of implementation and coupled with a way to measure users' needs, require knowing a user's goal to adapt efficiently, and can give rise to security and privacy issues because information is stored about users.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Tangible User Interfaces:

## Definition

A tangible user interface (TUI) is a user interface in which a person interacts with digital information through the physical environment.(no content)A tangible user interface represents the input directly in the physical world, and makes the digital information directly graspable.

## Purpose and Vision

The purpose of TUI development is to empower collaboration, learning, and design by giving physical forms to digital information, thus taking advantage of the human ability to grasp and manipulate physical objects and materials.(no content)A particular vision for tangible UIs, called Tangible Bits, is to give physical form to digital information, making bits directly manipulable and perceptible.

## Key Differences from GUIs

A GUI exists only in the digital world, whereas a TUI connects the digital with the physical world.(no content)An advantage is usability, because the user knows intuitively how to use the interface by knowing the function of the physical object, so the user does not need to learn the functionality.

## Pioneer Researchers

A pioneer in tangible user interfaces is Hiroshi Ishii, a professor at the MIT who heads the Tangible Media Group at the MIT Media Lab.(no content)In 1995, he joined the MIT Media Laboratory as a professor of Media Arts and Sciences, and founded the Tangible Media Group and started their ongoing Tangible Bits project.

## Examples

A simple example of tangible UI is the computer mouse: Dragging the mouse over a flat surface moves a pointer on the screen accordingly.(no content)Another example is the Marble Answering Machine by Durrell Bishop (1992), where a marble represents a single message left on the answering machine, and dropping a marble into a dish plays back the associated message or calls back the caller.

Links: [{"title":"Tangible user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tangible_user_interface"},{"title":"User interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_interface"},{"title":"Hiroshi Ishii (computer scientist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiroshi_Ishii_(computer_scientist)"},{"title":"Tangibility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tangibility"},{"title":"Audiocubes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audiocubes"},{"title":"Organic user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organic_user_interface"},{"title":"Natural user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_user_interface"},{"title":"Touch user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Touch_user_interface"},{"title":"Category:User interfaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:User_interfaces"},{"title":"Tangible media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?redirect=no&title=Tangible_media"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Tangible User Interfaces:

## Definition

A tangible user interface (TUI) is a user interface in which a person interacts with digital information through the physical environment.(no content)A tangible user interface represents the input directly in the physical world, and makes the digital information directly graspable.

## Purpose and Vision

The purpose of TUI development is to empower collaboration, learning, and design by giving physical forms to digital information, thus taking advantage of the human ability to grasp and manipulate physical objects and materials.(no content)A particular vision for tangible UIs, called Tangible Bits, is to give physical form to digital information, making bits directly manipulable and perceptible.

## Key Differences from GUIs

A GUI exists only in the digital world, whereas a TUI connects the digital with the physical world.(no content)An advantage is usability, because the user knows intuitively how to use the interface by knowing the function of the physical object, so the user does not need to learn the functionality.

## Pioneer Researchers

A pioneer in tangible user interfaces is Hiroshi Ishii, a professor at the MIT who heads the Tangible Media Group at the MIT Media Lab.(no content)In 1995, he joined the MIT Media Laboratory as a professor of Media Arts and Sciences, and founded the Tangible Media Group and started their ongoing Tangible Bits project.

## Examples

A simple example of tangible UI is the computer mouse: Dragging the mouse over a flat surface moves a pointer on the screen accordingly.(no content)Another example is the Marble Answering Machine by Durrell Bishop (1992), where a marble represents a single message left on the answering machine, and dropping a marble into a dish plays back the associated message or calls back the caller.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.text: Now let me update the todo list and run the validation script:

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
